H0.text: 0% is the probability that the offspring of a human parent homozygous for a V-shaped hairline (HH) and a parent homozygous for a straight hairline (hh) will have a straight hairline.

H1.text: 50% is the probability that the offspring of parents—one homozygous for a V‑shaped hairline (HH) and the other homozygous for a straight hairline (hh)—will have a straight hairline.

H2.text: 75% is the probability that offspring of a human pair consisting of a homozygous V‑shaped hairline parent (HH) and a homozygous straight hairline parent (hh) will have a straight hairline, given that V‑shaped hairline is dominant over straight.

H3.text: 100% is the probability that the offspring of humans with one parent homozygous for a V‑shaped hairline (HH) and the other homozygous for a straight hairline (hh) will have a straight hairline.

A4.text: If two parents are mated with each other who differ in one genetic characteristic for which they are both homozygous (each pure-bred), all offspring in the first generation (F1) are equal to the examined characteristic in genotype and phenotype showing the dominant trait.

A5.text: The principle of dominant inheritance discovered by Mendel states that in a heterozygote the dominant allele will cause the recessive allele to be 'masked': that is, not expressed in the phenotype.
